author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Muhammad Ali Has Long Had Book and Film Appeal
description: Two documentaries and a dramatized film in 2021 show the long-held fascination viewers have had with Ali, and the desire to revisit his life in the context of America’s recent history.
content: An hour into “Blood Brothers,” the Netflix documentary detailing the relationship between Muhammad Ali and Malcolm X, we see the young Black heavyweight champion looking perturbed during an interview with a white news reporter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Raw,’ ‘Monogamy’ and Other Streaming Gems
description: A look at off-the-radar recommendations for home viewing, including French horror, American romantic indies and Asian action selections.
content: In this month’s roundup of riskier streaming recommendations, we suggest the debut film from a recent Cannes winner, a handful of indies about the complexities of modern romance, a pair of high-energy Asian action flicks and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: An Italian Politician’s Quest for Attention Gets a Boost From Richard Gere
description: The actor may testify against Matteo Salvini, Italy’s former interior minister, in a case involving the treatment of migrants.
content: ROME — Matteo Salvini, the nationalist leader who as interior minister exercised enormous influence in Italy, lost his position in the cabinet and at the center of the spotlight, particularly after a new establishment prime minister effectively sidelined the country’s populists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: They lost their jobs to vaccine mandates.
content: Last week we told you about the Big Quit and the mass resignations happening across the U.S. as workers, empowered by pandemic-related circumstances, seek better opportunities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 25, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 25, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Great Performances’ and ‘In the Heights’
description: PBS’s “Great Performances” debuts a Halloween-themed episode. And “In the Heights” airs on HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 25-31. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Bitcoin Comes of Age
description: What does it mean now that cryptocurrency has joined proper society?
content: Bitcoin, which pushed past $66,000 last week, setting all-time price highs, has come a long way since January 2009, when a programmer with the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto introduced the cryptocurrency that would become a religion for some, a nuisance for others, and a looming threat to both the environment and the financial markets. It’s always a bit of a fool’s errand to try to explain why cryptocurrency prices go up or down, but last week’s rally coincided with the stock market debut of the first Bitcoin-related exchange-traded fund available to American investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Utah School District Ignored Racial Harassment for Years, Report Says
description: Black and Asian American students were often called racial slurs, while teachers and staff members ignored their complaints, the Justice Department found.
content: A school district in Utah ignored “serious and widespread” racial harassment for years, failing to respond to complaints from Black and Asian American students who were called racial slurs and physically assaulted by their peers, according to an investigation by the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Jewish Far-Right Pundit Splits the French Jewish Community as He Rises
description: Éric Zemmour, eyeing the presidency, tries to rehabilitate the wartime Vichy regime that collaborated with the Nazis as part of a campaign filled with provocations.
content: PARIS — There have been many startling elements to Éric Zemmour’s as yet undeclared campaign to forge a hard-right path to the French presidency, but perhaps none as surprising as his attempt to rehabilitate France’s collaborationist wartime regime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: PayPal says it isn’t interested in Pinterest, killing a potential $45 billion deal.
description: The payments firm squelched talk that it was seeking the social media platform “at this time.” A deal might have been worth about $45 billion.
content: PayPal, the digital payments giant, said late on Sunday that it was not interested in buying the social media network Pinterest, ending efforts to draft a potential $45 billion deal that would have been one of the biggest consumer internet takeovers in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Andrew Lloyd Webber Plays the Hits
description: The composer assumed the role of “D.J. Webz” for the after-party following the reopening of “The Phantom of the Opera.”
content: It was the reopening night of “The Phantom of the Opera” on Broadway, and Andrew Lloyd Webber was D.J.-ing the after-party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Inside the Big Facebook Leak
description: In a time of mega-leaks, journalists’ sources have become power players. Frances Haugen, the former Facebook product manager who shared company documents, led a meticulous media rollout.
content: Frances Haugen first met Jeff Horwitz, a tech-industry reporter for The Wall Street Journal, early last December on a hiking trail near the Chabot Space & Science Center in Oakland, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Biden and Democrats Push for Budget Deal This Week as Rifts Remain
description: Negotiators were closing in on a deal that could spend around $1.75 trillion, but lawmakers were still haggling over critical disagreements on the sprawling social policy bill.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Democratic congressional leaders raced on Monday to strike a compromise on a domestic policy and climate package, pushing for a vote within days even as critical disagreements remained over health benefits, paid leave, environmental provisions and how to pay for the sprawling plan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In a Tennessee City, a Confederate Statue Stays, but Gets Company
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 25, 2021.
content: “You can hear all these romanticized, ‘Gone With the Wind’ stories of slavery, but here is the reality: Where you are standing, men, women, boys and girls were bought like cattle. This happened.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: After 24 Years, a Conductor Returns to the Met Opera
description: Antonio Pappano is back for Wagner’s “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg” at a turning point in his career.
content: Among the ample attractions of the Metropolitan Opera’s forthcoming performances of Wagner’s “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg,” which runs from Tuesday through Nov. 14 with a cast including Michael Volle as Hans Sachs and Lise Davidsen as Eva, is the long-awaited return of the conductor Antonio Pappano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Dispatcher in Fatal Fire Hung Up on Victim Because He Spoke Spanish, Lawsuit Says
description: A group of former emergency dispatchers suing Lehigh County, Pa., in federal court said that operators routinely refused to use a translation service. The county disputes the allegations.
content: A group of former 911 dispatchers in Pennsylvania contends in a federal lawsuit filed this month that an Allentown man and his nephew died in a fire in 2020 after an emergency operator hung up on the man because he spoke Spanish — a claim that county officials dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Behold, the Worm Blob and Its Computerized Twin
description: It wriggles. It pulls. It falls apart and comes back together. It is everything you wish for and everything you fear.
content: In the wild, a worm blob looks like any other mud ball lolling around the bottom of a pond. But if you poke an unassuming worm blob, it will respond in a way a mud ball never would, wriggling out into a noodly shape that a Pastafarian might mistake for something divine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Democrats Are on the Verge of … Something
description: The politics of compromise are all happening on one side of the aisle.
content: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, the holiday season is almost upon us — if you presume we start off with Halloween, which is one of my favorites. Are you going to be dressing up as any famous person for parties?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: El Alfa, the King of Dembow, Dazzles at Madison Square Garden
description: The sold-out show by the Dominican artist was a watershed moment for the dembow movement.
content: “Who said the Dominican Republic couldn’t go global?” El Alfa announced in Spanish from the stage halfway through his first concert at Madison Square Garden, as red and blue Dominican flags fluttered across the crowd of thousands. The 30-year-old performer, born Emanuel Herrera Batista, had good reason to celebrate: On Friday night, the global ambassador of dembow became the genre’s first artist to sell out the storied venue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Vodka Rises From the Smoke of the California Wildfires
description: Hangar 1’s latest spirit is distilled from grapes damaged in the 2020 Glass fire.
content: Can there be an upside to wildfires that ravaged some California vineyards? At Hangar 1, a spirits company in Alameda, Calif., they may have found one. Smoke Point Vodka is distilled from the juice of Napa Valley merlot and malbec grapes damaged in the 2020 Glass fire. Crimson Wine Group, the owner of Pine Ridge Vineyards in the Stags Leap District, provided the fermented juice, made from grapes that were unsuited for wine. The result is an 80-proof vodka that’s not really smoky, but delivers aromas of anise and vanilla, and a spicy flavor that goes beyond the typically neutral profile of the spirit. Appreciate it on the rocks or in a vodka Gibson. Proceeds from sales are being donated to the California Fire Foundation, which supports firefighters and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Lynsey Chutel
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A failed playbook in Somalia.
content: After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the U.S. dispatched tens of thousands of troops to Afghanistan, a mission that recently ended in crushing defeat. But it turned to a different playbook in Somalia, relying on spies, Special Operations raids and drone strikes. Now, it seems, that playbook is also failing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Fired After Endorsing Vaccines, Evangelical Insider Takes a Leadership Role
description: Daniel Darling was at the center of a media storm over the summer. He hopes to lead a more civil discussion at Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary in Texas.
content: A year ago, Daniel Darling was following news reports about the development of the coronavirus vaccines with eager anticipation. His family had all had Covid-19 themselves, and his children had lost their beloved piano teacher, an otherwise healthy 50-year-old woman, to the virus. The pandemic was personal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Egypt’s Leader Ends State of Emergency, Says It’s No Longer Needed
description: The move by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi theoretically rolls back sweeping powers the government wielded in the name of fighting terrorism, but critics called it a cosmetic change.
content: CAIRO — Egypt’s authoritarian president announced Monday that he had lifted a four-year-old state of emergency, undoing powers that had given the government sweeping authority to quash protests, detain dissidents and control everyday life in the most populous Arab country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Moderna’s Covid vaccine produces a strong immune response in younger children, the company said.
description: The results were announced a day before an advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration is scheduled to review data for the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in children 5 through 11.
content: The coronavirus vaccine made by Moderna is safe and produces a powerful immune response in children 6 through 11, the company said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Officers to Testify About Eric Garner’s Death in Long-Delayed Inquiry
description: “What really happened on that day?” Gwen Carr, Eric Garner’s mother, asked about her son’s death on Staten Island seven years ago.
content: The anguished pleas of Eric Garner as he struggled in a New York City police officer’s chokehold in 2014 galvanized millions, and his last words — “I can’t breathe,” repeated 11 times and captured on video — became a rallying cry for a protest movement demanding that police officers be held accountable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesco Lastrucci
title: Inside the Thai Temple Where Tattoos Come to Life
description: Wat Bang Phra, a temple in central Thailand, is renowned as a center for sak yant, a style of tattoo art believed by some to convey protective powers.
content: The sky was streaked with purple when I boarded the early-morning train from Bangkok to the Nakhon Chai Si District in central Thailand. For the entire hourlong ride, a monk sat quietly in front of me, smiling, gusts of wind swirling the orange robes over his tattoos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Tale of Two Infields Pits Strength Against Strength
description: Houston and Atlanta have continuity to spare. The connections between this year’s World Series teams are numerous, especially with their homegrown cores.
content: HOUSTON — Two were drafted first overall. Two have won their league’s Most Valuable Player Award. They come from all over: Cuba and Curaçao, Puerto Rico and Venezuela, California and Georgia and Mississippi and New Mexico. And all of them have played for only one team in the majors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook profits jump 17 percent.
description: The results in the latest quarter are a sign of the company’s financial strength as it faces a public relations crisis.
content: Facebook said on Monday that revenue rose 35 percent to $29 billion in the three months ending in September compared with the same period last year, while profits rose 17 percent to $9.2 billion, a sign of the social network’s financial strength as it faces a public relations crisis over troubling disclosures made by a former employee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Luke Vander Ploeg, Stella Tan, Alexandra Leigh Young, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges and Chris Wood
title: A Threat to China’s Economy
description: Evergrande, a property giant, is teetering on the edge of collapse. Here’s what its troubles might reveal about a country that prides itself on stability and control.
content: Every once in a while a company grows so big and messy that governments fear what would happen to the broader economy if it were to fail. In China, Evergrande, a sprawling real estate developer, is that company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: For Shakshuka or What Have You
description: New York Shuk’s latest condiments provide the backbone to shakshuka, but they also work as a dip or spread.
content: With their ever-increasing line of products bearing the New York Shuk label, Ron and Leetal Arazi are putting the Middle East, with an emphasis on Jewish and Moroccan flavors, on the table. Their latest is a thick, all-purpose tomato-based condiment called matbucha, a homemade staple of North African origin that is ubiquitous in Israeli households. On its own it’s a dip. But it’s also a base for shakshuka, a topping for pizza or crostini, a ketchup replacement, a pasta sauce, an addition to steamed clams or mussels and an excellent coating on fish before baking. The signature matbucha has some heat; the matbucha with olives and mint offers a tart edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook Wrestles With the Features It Used to Define Social Networking
description: Likes and shares made the social media site what it is. Now, company documents show, it’s struggling to deal with their effects.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2019, Facebook researchers began a new study of one of the social network’s foundational features: the Like button.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Baseball, Popular but No Longer Dominant, Seeks to Reclaim Its Cool
description: Facing a loss of cultural cachet, Major League Baseball is working to build a more diverse audience and exploring ways to liven up the game.
content: BOSTON — Across the United States, baseball, long considered the national pastime, is still popular by most measures. Millions go to games each year, millions more watch on television, and quite a few will turn their attention to the Fall Classic — the 117th World Series — which begins on Tuesday in Houston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Google Pixel 6 Review: Playing Catch-Up With the iPhone
description: With long battery life and nice cameras, the new Google devices excel at what popular phones have done for years. Is that enough?
content: For half a decade, Google, the maker of Android, the world’s most widely used phone software, has had a dream to make a best-selling phone that rivals the gold standard, the iPhone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Niraj Chokshi
title: Tesla Value Tops $1 Trillion After Hertz Orders 100,000 Cars
description: The order, to be fulfilled between now and the end of next year, is a sign of the growing momentum in the shift toward electric cars.
content: Hertz said on Monday that it would convert more than 20 percent of its rental fleet to Tesla’s electric cars by the end of next year, an announcement that helped propel Tesla’s stock value beyond $1 trillion for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: FSG Promotes Mitzi Angel to President
description: A publisher and editor who has worked with Sally Rooney, Garth Greenwell and Amia Srinivasan, she will be the first woman to lead the 75-year-old publishing house.
content: Mitzi Angel, the publisher of Farrar, Straus and Giroux — who as an editor signed Sally Rooney and Garth Greenwell — will add the title of president to her role at the storied literary publishing house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Picking Their Fights
description: Creating temporary government programs could have big political benefits for Democrats.
content: President Biden and congressional Democrats are now trying to cut their original $3.5 trillion family-policy plan roughly in half, so that it can win enough moderate votes to pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: hasten
description: This word has appeared in 104 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Decoding Eric Adams
description: He is poised to become the next mayor. He could be the biggest City Hall wild card in decades.
content: It’s Monday. With the Nov. 2 election eight days away, we’ll look at Eric Adams, the globe-trotting, meditating former police officer who is poised to be New York’s next mayor. We’ll also look at a high-tech take on the player pianos of a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Recap, Season 3, Episode 2: ‘Judasing’
description: Kendall makes his pitch. Even with his siblings, he sounds like a guest on “Power Lunch.”
content: There’s a mad genius to the way Kendall Roy uses language. Here’s a guy who essentially learned to communicate by listening to cable TV panelists, leadership conference speakers and the macho bluster of his venture capitalist college bros. Now, in an ever-intensifying national spotlight, Ken is tossing around jargon with a frenzied, improvisational flair, like a jazz singer scatting in double-time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Are Vaccine Boosters Widely Needed? Some Federal Advisers Have Misgivings.
description: “In our hearts, I think people don’t quite agree with this notion of a booster dose,” said one leading vaccine expert.
content: Following a series of endorsements over the last month by scientific panels advising federal agencies, tens of millions of Americans are now eligible for booster shots of coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The New Billionaire Tax in Democrats’ Sights
description: Leaders are weighing a new charge on unrealized capital gains for the ultrawealthy.
content: As Democrats race to find ways to pay for President Biden’s social spending plans — particularly as one of their own, Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, blocks efforts to raise corporate and individual tax rates — they’re increasingly turning their eyes to a different kind of tax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Mike Isaac
title: Facebook Whistle-Blower Brings Campaign to Europe After Disclosures
description: Beginning a European tour in Britain, the former Facebook manager was questioned by policymakers drafting tougher tech regulations.
content: LONDON — Facebook has lurched from controversy to controversy since Mark Zuckerberg started it as a Harvard undergrad in 2004. But the actions of Frances Haugen, a former product manager, have created a backlash and public relations crisis that stand apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Border Patrol Repeatedly Gave Agents Light Punishments, Report Finds
description: After an inquiry into a private Facebook group where racist memes were shared, 60 employees were found to have violated the agency’s code of conduct. Two were fired.
content: WASHINGTON — After it was revealed in 2019 that scores of border officials belonged to a private Facebook group that contained racist and otherwise offensive posts, investigations into the misconduct resulted in minimal discipline, according to a House Oversight and Reform Committee report released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkish President Steps Back From Expulsions of 10 Western Diplomats
description: The threatened expulsions had risked severe economic consequences and a rupture in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
content: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey stepped back on Monday from a threat to expel 10 Western ambassadors, averting a diplomatic storm that analysts and diplomats were warning would bring economic disaster upon Turkey and a lasting rupture in the NATO alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Woman Convicted of a Crime Against Humanity in Death of Yazidi Child
description: The woman was sentenced to 10 years in prison after a court found that she joined the Islamic State and enslaved a Yazidi mother and child, whom she left to die in the summer heat of Iraq in 2015.
content: BERLIN — A criminal court in Munich sentenced a German convert to Islam to 10 years in prison on Monday, finding the woman guilty of supporting the Islamic State in Iraq and a crime against humanity for leaving a 5-year-old Yazidi girl to die of thirst in the scorching heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Angelo
title: There Is a New Kidnapping Capital of the World. Here’s What We Need to Do About It.
description: To restore stability in Haiti, the government must get the gangs under control. International actors also have an important role to play.
content: Port-au-Prince, Haiti, has become the world’s kidnapping capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: A Surprise for Two ‘Creatives’: An Artists’ Loft in the East Village
description: Amanda Paulsen and Peter Zusman found a 1,000-square-foot space on Avenue C for $3,200 a month — with a basement and a backyard.
content: “It was a very lax process.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Daniel Jones’s Big Play Shows the Giants’ Bullheaded Approach
description: The Giants quarterback was applauded for his toughness after making a rare reception. But considering Jones’s recent head injury, our columnist asks why the play was even called.
content: The longest play on the Giants’ first touchdown drive on Sunday involved Daniel Jones and a leaping, one-handed reception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Meatto
title: Learning About Latin American and Hispanic Culture and History Through Music
description: In these three short lesson plans based on Times resources, students explore the history of reggaeton, the legacy of the Tejano star Selena and the diversity of Cuba’s music.
content: How can music represent a mix of cultures? What role does music play in our diverse identities? How can music reveal complex histories? These are some of the questions explored by the short lesson plans below as they spotlight three examples of music from Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Tax the Rich, Help America’s Children
description: Democrats’ plans aren’t “Marxism.” They’re as American as apple pie.
content: Democrats may — may — finally be about to agree on a revenue and spending plan. It will clearly be smaller than President Biden’s original proposal, and much smaller than what progressives wanted. It will, however, be infinitely bigger than what Republicans would have done, because if the G.O.P. controlled Congress, we would be doing nothing at all to invest in America’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh, Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
title: Sudan’s Military Seizes Power, Casting Democratic Transition Into Chaos
description: Civilian and military leaders were supposed to share power after a popular uprising in 2019 overthrew a decades-long dictatorship. On Monday the military detained the civilian prime minister.
content: Sudan’s top generals seized power on Monday, arresting the prime minister, imposing a state of emergency and opening fire on protesters, in tumultuous scenes that threatened to derail the transition to democracy in an African nation just as it emerged from decades of harsh autocratic rule and international isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Manchin pushes for more climate cuts from the budget bill.
description: He has already effectively succeeded in stripping the bill of its most powerful climate change provision.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has pushed Democrats to drop or weaken a second major climate change provision from the sweeping social policy and environmental spending bill that the White House hopes to finalize this week, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Shooting at Boise Mall Leaves 2 Dead and 5 Injured, Including Suspect
description: A police officer was among those injured at Boise Towne Square in Idaho, and a suspect was critically injured in a shootout with the police.
content: Two people were killed and five injured during a shooting at a mall in Boise, Idaho, on Monday afternoon in which the assailant traded gunfire with the police, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway’s ‘Is This a Room’ and ‘Dana H.’ to Close Early
description: The two experimental works will end their runs on Nov. 14. They had been scheduled to close Jan. 16.
content: A pair of short experimental dramas that made an unlikely journey to Broadway this fall will close early, reflecting a tough climate for new plays as the industry seeks to recover from the lengthy pandemic shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Come for the Focaccia, Stay for the History
description: “Liguria the Cookbook,” from Laurel Evans, shows the breadth of the Italian region’s cuisine.
content: The province of Liguria on the northwest Italian coast has a diverse cuisine that varies greatly from the coast to the inland regions. Along the sea, the necklace of Italian Riviera resorts and the cosmopolitan city of Genoa serve elegant fare like stuffed veal rolls, decorative corzetti pasta, zucchini flowers and specialties also typical of the neighboring Côte d’Azur, like chickpea fritters and little stuffed vegetables. It’s also the land of cucina povera, with foraged herbs, salt cod and gnocchi made from chestnut flour and it is all connected by the region’s ubiquitous, verdant pesto; slabs of focaccia (always thinner than you might expect) and an appetite for things that are stuffed or fried or both. Sturdy marjoram and rosemary are used as often as Genoese basil (a small round-leaf variety very unlike what’s sold in American markets). This mixture of styles is beautifully presented in “Liguria,” an informative new cookbook by Laurel Evans, a Texan who married a Ligurian and sought the culinary secrets of his extended family and friends. Worth discovering are a walnut and garlic sauce for pasta, lettuce packets stuffed with meat and herbs, fried sage leaves to nibble while sipping the regional vermentino and delicious stewed rabbit with olives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Sudan’s military seizes power.
content: Sudan’s military seized power on Monday, detaining the prime minister and other civilian political leaders. The unfolding coup appeared to deal a sweeping blow to hopes for a democratic transition in one of Africa’s largest countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘The Chancellor’ Portrays Angela Merkel as a Droll Source of Sanity in a Mad World
description: Kati Marton’s biography charts Merkel’s childhood in East Germany, her slow entrance into politics and her four terms as the leader of her country.
content: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is famous for her plain but direct style. “I have no charisma,” she once complained to Tony Blair, “and I’m not good at communicating.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: I’m Not a Pilot, but I Just Flew a Helicopter Over California
description: New technology, a few iPads and a quick tutorial can help anyone act like a pilot. Dealing with air traffic control is another matter.
content: CAMARILLO, Calif. — On a recent Wednesday afternoon, I flew a helicopter over Ventura County, just north of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s visit to New Jersey highlights a debate over SALT.
description: The SALT limit helped Democrats capture some House seats previously held by Republicans in New Jersey, California and elsewhere. Many of those representatives are pushing to lift the cap now.
content: President Biden was in New Jersey on Monday to champion his efforts to pass legislation investing in early childhood education and passenger rail service. But the backdrop highlighted a simmering dispute among Democrats that is hampering Mr. Biden’s legislative agenda: whether to lift the limit on a tax deduction that largely benefits high earners in states like New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A BRIC in Flux Turns Out an Intimate, Focused JazzFest
description: Though it was operating on fewer cylinders because of the pandemic, for the first time in its seven-year history the event sold out all three nights of music in Brooklyn.
content: As jazz festivals go, BRIC JazzFest is on the small but ambitious side, aspiring to a few ideas at once. It operates in Brooklyn with something close to Manhattan-scale resources, but like BRIC’s flagship music series, the Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival, it aims to serve a broad audience, not a particularly affluent one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: This Year’s Thanksgiving Feast Will Wallop the Wallet
description: Nearly every ingredient, from the turkey to the after-dinner coffee, is expected to cost more, for a host of reasons.
content: Thanksgiving 2021 could be the most expensive meal in the history of the holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1 Million Homes in California
description: A Queen Anne house in San Diego, a two-bedroom condominium in Berkeley and a midcentury-modern home in Altadena.
content: This remarkably well-kept home has many features associated with Queen Anne style, including gables trimmed in fish-scale shingles and delicately carved railings framing interior and exterior stairs. It is about two blocks away from another notable Queen Anne house: Villa Montezuma, a historic house museum run by the city of San Diego.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Spooky Pasta and Ghastly Cookies
description: The Brooklyn Kitchen is leading two frightfully tasty cooking classes on Halloween weekend.
content: In the run-up to Halloween, the Brooklyn Kitchen, which just started giving cooking classes in the Essex Market on the Lower East Side, has scheduled hands-on lessons for savories and sweets for the holiday. Halloween pasta — black squid ink with a lemon-herb sauce and pumpkin gnocchi with a brown butter and sage sauce — will be taught Saturday from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., $100 plus a $15 service fee. Halloween cookie decorating is the subject on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., $65 plus a $9.75 service fee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Pomfret
title: They Trusted the C.I.A. It Was a Mistake.
description: The roots of this special relationship stretch back to the Cold War. It’s a story of bravery, blood bonds and, of course, betrayal.
content: The C.I.A. has the closest relationships with the intelligence services from other English-speaking democracies — Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. So close that their alliance is named the Five Eyes. Even make-believe American and British operatives are thick as thieves. James Bond’s compadre is none other than the C.I.A. officer Felix Leiter, who returns in the latest Bond thriller, “No Time to Die.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua M. Bernstein
title: Last Call for the Beer Bar?
description: Once the best place in town to discover new craft beers, bars are finding it hard to compete with brewery taprooms.
content: When Chris Black opened Falling Rock Tap House in downtown Denver in 1997 with his brothers, Steve and Al, he sought the hoppy summit. The bar and its “no crap on tap” ethos grew to include 94 rotating drafts showcasing American brewing’s blossoming beers, especially during the city’s annual Great American Beer Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Who is Abdalla Hamdok, the Sudanese prime minister detained in a military coup?
description: Sudan’s  prime minister spent much of his career at international institutions before joining his country’s government. Now he has been forced out.
content: Until a military coup in Sudan, Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok had the daunting task of trying to liberalize his country and lead it to democracy after three decades of dictatorship, while revitalizing its battered economy and normalizing relations with the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Facebook Papers and their fallout.
description: A look at a month of scrutiny and struggles for the social-networking giant.
content: For weeks, Facebook has been shaken by revelations that have ignited a firestorm of criticism from lawmakers, regulators and the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Domestic Prosciutto From the Ozarks
description: True Story Foods dry-ages its new prosciutto for 10 months.
content: There’s a new domestic prosciutto from True Story Foods with a personality all its own. It’s a mellow, silky ham, less robust and salty than some, but lovely on a charcuterie board or in a sandwich. Russ Kremer, a Missouri hog farmer and partner based in the foothills of the Ozarks, has established a network of more than 150 participating farmers raising heritage breeds for True Story’s prosciutto. The hams are dry-aged for 10 months in the Poconos with just sea salt. The prosciutto is sold sliced in packages from which they’re easily separated, unlike some other brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: The World ‘Has Found a Way to Do This’: The U.S. Lags on Paid Leave
description: The U.S. is one of six countries with no national paid leave. The Democrats have cut their plan to four weeks, which would still make it an outlier.
content: Congress is now considering four weeks of paid family and medical leave, down from the 12 weeks that were initially proposed in the Democrats’ spending plan. If the plan becomes law, the United States will no longer be one of six countries in the world — and the only rich country — without any form of national paid leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Proposed Tax on Billionaires Raises Question: What’s Income?
description: Democrats are homing in on unrealized capital gains raises as a way to help fund their social spending bill.
content: After months of negotiations over President Biden’s big social spending bill, congressional Democrats looking for ways to pay for it have zeroed in on America’s billionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Music Are You Listening to Right Now?
description: How do you find out about new music? What is one new song you think everyone should hear?
content: Is music a big part of your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: Read It and Scream
description: Here are eight knuckle-biting, nerve-ripping new tales, just in time for Halloween.
content: Overcoming dark times is the point of every scary story ever told. Whether it be pestilence or zombies, ravenous phantoms or vengeful witches, killers or psychos or ghouls from the beyond — the dramatic experience of being afraid, and the exhilaration of living through what we fear, bolster our will to survive. It may be as ancient as our ancestors telling stories around a fire, or as modern as a night alone with a horror novel, but the experience of imagining that which frightens us is a deeply human defense for life’s pageant of horrors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: ‘Insecure’ Season 5, Episode 1 Recap: No Time to Be Insecure
description: The characters of “Insecure” set off to close out their final season with intention.
content: During the first episode of the final season of HBO’s “Insecure,” we meet “Throwback Issa,” the college-aged version of Issa staring back at her in the bathroom mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: Madagascar’s Got Talent: Lemurs That Sing With Rhythm
description: For the first time, researchers have found a nonhuman animal that seems to have a sense of the beat.
content: Our distant primate relative, the Indri indri, is a critically endangered species of lemur found only in Madagascar. These black-and-white primates are the weight of a small dog and look like a cross between a cat and a koala. And they sound — depending on whom you ask — like the shriek of a balloon quickly releasing air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Another Victim of a Serial Killer Is Identified, 4 Decades After His Death
description: For years, some of the victims of John Wayne Gacy had gone unidentified. DNA and expanding genealogical databases allowed officials to identify a victim this month.
content: CHICAGO — Authorities in Cook County have identified another victim of John Wayne Gacy, the serial killer who terrorized Chicago in the 1970s, murdering dozens of young men and burying their bodies at his suburban home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Halloween’ and the Problem With Its Sequels
description: The follow-ups took the wrong lessons from the 1978 film. But we keep giving the franchise second chances, in hopes a new one will live up to the original.
content: The astonishing opening-weekend grosses for “Halloween Kills,” the 12th film in the durable “Halloween” franchise, may have surprised some observers — after all, audiences are still hesitant to visit theaters, and reviews for this installment were not kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Where Citrus Is the Star
description: Butterfield Market is highlighting some harder-to-find produce this winter.
content: The colder months feature citrus. This year, Evan Obsatz, an owner of the Butterfield Markets on the Upper East Side, and his produce specialist, John Weintraub, have gathered offbeat varieties of the fruit in the Madison Avenue store. Yuzu, a green- or yellow-skinned fruit with a flavor that’s increasingly popular thanks to Japanese chefs but hard to find fresh, is being sold, as are striped Eureka lemons with tart pink flesh, Cthulhu-like Buddha’s hands, blood oranges, big etrogs (citrons), makrut limes, pomelos and more. Try the yuzu or the makrut in your next gin and tonic. The availability may vary throughout the season but many varieties should be on hand through February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley
title: Loose and Boxed Ammunition Found at Scene of Alec Baldwin Shooting
description: Court papers did not specify what kind of ammunition detectives recovered from a movie set where the actor had fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun he was told did not contain live rounds.
content: Detectives found three revolvers, spent casings and ammunition — in boxes, loose and in a fanny pack — when they searched the New Mexico film set where the actor Alec Baldwin fatally shot a cinematographer last week with a gun he had been told did not contain any live rounds, according to an inventory of the items seized that was released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Missing Foreign Workers Add to Hiring Challenges
description: Fewer foreign people have been able to work in the U.S. amid the coronavirus, leaving a hole in the potential labor force.
content: Neha Mahajan was a television journalist in India before her husband’s job moved her family to the United States in 2008. She spent years locked out of the labor market, confined by what she calls the “gilded cage” of her immigration status — one that the pandemic placed her back into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Past and Future of People’s Park
description: Leaders at the University of California have decided to build dorms on the storied park in Berkeley.
content: On the final day of September, the leaders of the University of California system voted to build student dorms near one of their biggest campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Jesus Jiménez
title: James Michael Tyler, Who Played Gunther on ‘Friends,’ Dies at 59
description: A real barista who was cast as a Central Perk co-worker of his crush, Jennifer Aniston’s character, he appeared in 150 episodes of the hit show.
content: James Michael Tyler, who played the deadpan, smitten barista Gunther on the TV show “Friends,” died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why Republican Ken Buck Believes in Antitrust and Doesn’t Believe in the ‘Big Lie’
description: The congressman discusses the future of his party and why he’s teaming up with Democrats on a bipartisan effort that could break up big tech.
content: Representative Ken Buck has joined forces with the Democratic congressman David Cicilline and others to push through a package of antitrust legislation that could prove damning to companies like Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook. “As a conservative, I don’t think big is bad. I think big is great,” he says. But at the same time, he is quick to clarify that Silicon Valley isn’t the land of “benevolent monopolists” and that leaders like Jeff Bezos need to be more transparent about their business practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Eddie Rosario Is Looking Good
description: An unheralded pickup at the trading deadline, Rosario has been on a tear, powering Atlanta through the playoffs. Can the M.V.P. of the N.L.C.S. keep it going?
content: HOUSTON — Never in his life has Eddie Rosario looked this good at the plate. And that’s not just a matter of his numbers in a torrid eight days that saw him named the most valuable player of the National League Championship Series, pushing the Atlanta Braves into their first World Series since 1999.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Troops opened fire on pro-democracy protesters who flooded the streets, with at least two reported killed.
description: Protesters against the military coup took to the streets by the thousands and barricaded roads, and soldiers reportedly shot demonstrators outside army headquarters.
content: Troops fired on demonstrators outside the Sudanese army headquarters, killing at least three people and injuring more than 80, according to a doctors’ group, as pro-democracy protesters flooded into the streets of the capital, Khartoum, on Monday, after the military mounted a coup, detaining the prime minister, suspending the government and declaring a state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A 100-Year-Old Priest Was Nudged From His Parish. He Has No Plan to Retire.
description: The Rev. Luis Urriza arrived in Beaumont, Texas, nearly 70 years ago and founded the thriving Cristo Rey parish. His religious order has now called him back to Spain.
content: BEAUMONT, Texas — The priest needed a hand while tugging on layer after layer of vestments. He carried a magnifying glass to help him read a handwritten list of prayer intentions. But as he jingled a bell to let the congregation know that Mass was beginning, he abandoned his walker and cane, singing along with the choir as he ambled up the center aisle toward the altar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Unvaccinated children and some people from countries with low rates will be exempted from new U.S. travel rules.
description: The Biden administration has announced that it would lift travel restrictions on Nov. 8 and reopen the United States to fully vaccinated international travelers.
content: Children under the age of 18 who are unvaccinated against the coronavirus, and a limited category of foreigners arriving from countries with low vaccination rates, are among the travelers exempted from forthcoming requirements that will determine who can enter the United States, Biden administration officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The Rich World’s Promise of $100 Billion in Climate Aid Inches Forward
description: Diplomats announced a plan to make good on an unkept promise of climate aid, a key point of tension in upcoming global climate talks.
content: Money that was supposed to be on the table last year will most likely be on the table next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Julia Jacobs
title: Alec Baldwin Was Rehearsing Pointing Gun at Camera, Affidavit Says
description: The director of “Rust” gave the authorities the most detailed account yet of how the actor fatally shot the film’s cinematographer.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — Alec Baldwin was rehearsing a scene that involved pointing a revolver “towards the camera lens” when the gun — which the crew had been told did not contain live rounds — suddenly went off and killed the cinematographer, according to the film’s director, who was quoted in an affidavit released Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks
title: Tensions between Sudan’s military and politicians grew in the past few months.
description: Civilians were set to rule the country for the first time in more than three decades. But the military was concerned about losing power.
content: The weeks leading up to Monday’s coup in Sudan were fraught with tensions between the military and civilian leadership, which were battling to gain control of the nation’s future as a key deadline approached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley
title: Questions on Baldwin Shooting Turn to Assistant Director
description: Complaints have emerged about his oversight of safety measures on previous productions.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — In the frantic moments after Alec Baldwin shot the cinematographer and the director of a Western being filmed in New Mexico, a script supervisor on the set called 911 with a desperate plea for help.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Whose Promised Land?A Journey Into a Divided Israel
description: Two Times journalists drive the length of Israel to discover what it means to be Israeli today. They meet a kaleidoscope of people, searching for belonging but far apart on how to find it.
content: We found Shai Melamud just before dusk, standing on his patio near Israel’s northern border, opposite a slope scorched black by recent rocket fire from Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: How Atlanta, in a Season of Obstacles, Made the World Series
description: “Everything you could possibly see in a road, we hit it,” first baseman Freddie Freeman said. And yet.
content: ATLANTA — An October tradition that arrives without fail with every World Series is discussion of resilience and perseverance and how the teams that made it had overcome all manner of season-threatening menaces along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Dave Chappelle responds to Netflix controversy with a video clip from his concert.
description: Mr. Chappelle’s special has put Netflix at the center of a conversation involving transphobia, free speech and employee activism.
content: Dave Chappelle responded to the controversy over his Netflix standup special “The Closer” — which has been criticized as promoting bigotry toward transgender people — by posting a five-minute video clip to Instagram on Monday in which he denied that he had been invited to speak to transgender employees of the streaming service and refused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon workers on Staten Island show they have enough support to hold a union election.
description: The outcome could bring a second unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse in less than a year.
content: A fledgling union of employees at four Amazon warehouses on Staten Island demonstrated on Monday that they had enough worker interest to hold an election to form a union, the National Labor Relations Board said. The agency’s determination lays the groundwork for the second unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse in less than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: This Flu Season Is Different. Here’s How to Prepare.
description: We’ve had two light years in a row, which some experts worry could mean we’ll be in for a rough few months.
content: One silver lining of the last two winters is that the flu, which typically sends hundreds of thousands of Americans to the hospital each year and causes tens of thousands of deaths, was not as severe as it has been in years past. Peter Palese, a microbiologist and flu expert at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York City, said there were 100 times fewer infections, hospitalizations and deaths from influenza last season than in average flu seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Nadelson
title: An Ice-Cream Parlor Where Time Stands Still
description: At Eddie’s Sweet Shop in Queens, the malts, shakes and sundaes are still made almost exactly as they were in the 1960s.
content: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annelise Riles
title: Biden Has a Chance to Go Big and Bold at the Fed
description: With new appointments, the president has a chance to overhaul the stale culture of central banking.
content: President Biden will soon have an opportunity to appoint two new members of the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors and renew or replace the chair and vice chair. These officials regulate many of our financial institutions. They play a central role in keeping prices in check and employment stable — no small order, especially amid the turbulent Covid-era economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: The U.S. cut off aid to the Sudanese government after the coup.
description: The Biden administration, calling for immediate restoration of the transition government, froze $700 million in direct aid.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States froze $700 million in direct assistance to Sudan’s government in response to Monday’s coup, and American officials demanded that the Sudanese military immediately release civilian leaders and restore the transitional government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oyinkan Braithwaite
title: A Virgin Homicide as Told by the Girls She Left Behind
description: Kwon Yeo-sun’s “Lemon” revisits an 18-year-old’s murder from three biased perspectives.
content: LEMON By Kwon Yeo-sun Translated by Janet Hong
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Calarco
title: ‘There’s Almost No Incentive at All to Give Him the Vaccine.’
description: A “moral calm” is holding parents back from vaccinating their kids.
content: Before the Covid-19 pandemic, a mother I interviewed as part of my study on pandemic parenting said, she never had a problem with vaccines. Her 2-year-old son got all his recommended immunizations on schedule. When it comes to the Covid-19 vaccines, however, the mother, who is white and has a college degree, says she isn’t so sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Emotional Toll of Adult Acne
description: The skin blemishes can affect people in their 30s, 40s and beyond and lead to depression, anxiety and social isolation.
content: No matter how much we claim to value people’s inner worth over their outward appearance, what we see upon meeting someone for the first time can color our assessment of the person’s value. At least, that’s what many adults with acne fear, prompting them to shun social or professional encounters lest their facial blemishes result in a bad impression or even rejection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Chute
title: History and Its Harsh Lessons Give These Graphic Novels Their Material
description: In Hillary Chute’s Graphic Content column, she looks at Nora Krug’s graphic adaptation of Timothy Snyder’s “On Tyranny” and Dash Shaw’s “Discipline.”
content: Timothy Snyder’s “On Tyranny: Twenty Lessons From the Twentieth Century” appeared in 2017 during a time of postelection panic in the United States. His deep knowledge as a historian of modern Europe allowed him to identify links between fascism, past and present, and also to offer practical advice. A small book, almost a pamphlet (that so-called impulse buy that often sits near the register), and anchored largely in lessons from the Holocaust and from Russian totalitarianism, it was a best seller, readable and galvanizing. Snyder refused to name Trump in its pages, referring instead to “a president.” Now he’s out with ON TYRANNY: Twenty Lessons From the Twentieth Century: Graphic Edition (Ten Speed, $24), brilliantly illustrated by the German cartoonist Nora Krug, and updated to include allusions to Covid-19 (also unnamed). I sometimes sigh at all the graphic adaptations out there, many of which are unnecessary. Not this one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Birdsall
title: One Baker’s Quest to Make Bread That Blurs Borders
description: Don Guerra, a leader of the local-grain movement in Tucson, is challenging others to reimagine craft baking with an eye toward its Latino and Indigenous roots.
content: TUCSON, Ariz. — The July sun was barely up, but the heat was already inching well above comfortable. Don Guerra seemed unfazed, though, as if the desert had long ago settled in his bones. He had been moving briskly since 4 a.m. to the clanking soundtrack of an integrated loader, the stiff canvas conveyor belt that sends raw torpedoes of pain au levain onto the decks of his four-level oven at Barrio Bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Lauren Hirsch
title: E-sports joins the SPAC craze as FaZe Clan seeks to go public.
description: The deal to join the stock market through a merger with a shell company would value the e-sports conglomerate at about $1 billion.
content: FaZe Clan, the e-sports conglomerate, announced on Monday that it planned to join the public markets in a deal that involves merging with a special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC, which would value it at about $1 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Joseph Goldstein
title: New York City’s biggest police union sues over the city’s vaccine mandate.
description: The Police Benevolent Association of New York said it opposed a vaccine mandate for police officers that does not allow the option of being tested weekly instead of being vaccinated.
content: The largest police union in New York City asked a judge on Monday to allow unvaccinated police officers to continue working, despite the city’s recently imposed vaccine mandate, which requires all municipal workers to have received at least one coronavirus vaccine dose by Nov. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Budget, Facebook, Sudan: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Adele Is No. 1 Once Again, With ‘Easy on Me’
description: The singer’s long-awaited comeback single is No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 singles chart with 54 million streams and strong showings for downloads and radio play.
content: After a six-year wait, new music by Adele was sure to be a hit. But how big of one, especially for a song like “Easy on Me” — a classic piano torch ballad that ignores virtually all contemporary pop standards — was unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Ignoring Sanctions, Russia Renews Broad Cybersurveillance Operation
description: The new campaign came only months after President Biden imposed sanctions on Moscow in response to a series of spy operations it had conducted around the world.
content: SEA ISLAND, Ga. — Russia’s premier intelligence agency has launched another campaign to pierce thousands of U.S. government, corporate and think-tank computer networks, Microsoft officials and cybersecurity experts warned on Sunday, only months after President Biden imposed sanctions on Moscow in response to a series of sophisticated spy operations it had conducted around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: With New Conviction, Hong Kong Uses Security Law to Clamp Down on Speech
description: An activist, Ma Chun-man, was convicted of inciting secession after, he said, he chanted slogans to test the limits of the law.
content: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong court on Monday convicted an activist of inciting secession for shouting pro-independence slogans at a series of protests, underlining the power of a sweeping national security law to punish speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Why Amazon Is in Business With Judge Judy
description: The company hopes a new court show starring the straight-talking judge will help turbocharge its free, ad-supported streaming platform, IMDb TV.
content: CULVER CITY, Calif. — And you thought Amazon’s ambitions in Hollywood were limited to a single streaming service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The First Thing We Do, Let’s Kill All the Leaf Blowers
description: Nearly everything about how Americans “care” for their lawns is deadly, but these machines exist in a category of environmental hell all their own.
content: NASHVILLE — Into these perfect October afternoons, when light gleams on the red dogwood berries and the blue arrowwood berries and the purple beautyberries; on the last of the many-colored zinnias and the last of the yellow marigolds and the last of the white snakeroot flowers; on the shining hair of babies in strollers and the shining ponytails of young mothers and the tender, shining heads of old men walking dogs — into the midst of all this beauty, the kind of beauty that makes despair seem like only a figment of the midnight imagination, the monsters arrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Gene Freidman, ‘Taxi King’ Who Upended His Industry, Dies at 50
description: He bid up the price of medallions and borrowed against them. When their value plummeted, immigrant cabbies were left deep in debt.
content: Gene Freidman, a cabdriver’s son who schemed his way to become the nation’s biggest taxi mogul and came to personify both the inflated ascent of the industry in New York City and its crushing financial collapse, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Child Who Survived Gondola Crash Should Live in Italy, Israel Court Rules
description: Eitan Biran, the 6-year-old survivor of a cable car accident in Italy, should live there with his aunt, not his grandfather in Israel, ruled a judge in Tel Aviv.
content: TEL AVIV — An Israeli family court ruled Monday that the 6-year-old survivor of an Italian cable car crash should live with his paternal aunt in Italy, not with the maternal grandfather who had spirited him off to Israel in what the court said was a violation of international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company Wants to Build a Space Station
description: Blue Origin says it will team up with Sierra Space, Boeing and other companies to build an outpost that could help replace the International Space Station.
content: Blue Origin, the space company owned by Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, is teaming up with other firms to build a space station in Earth orbit. The group announced its plans on Monday, revealing the latest concept for a privately built orbital outpost that could replace or complement the International Space Station.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Seattle Kraken Make Their Home Debut
description: Fans celebrated the arrival of pro hockey in Seattle, though the Kraken lost to their new regional rival, the Vancouver Canucks.
content: Fans celebrated the arrival of pro hockey in Seattle, though the Kraken lost to their new regional rival, the Vancouver Canucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Is It Covid-19 or the Flu?
description: Though the symptoms of flu and Covid-19 can be similar, there are ways to tell them apart. Here’s how.
content: Though the symptoms of flu and Covid-19 can be similar, there are ways to tell them apart. Here’s how.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: California Drought Turns to Deluge
description: After months of drought and wildfire, a storm drenched Northern California with much-needed water, along with powerful winds and flooding.
content: After months of drought and wildfire, a storm drenched Northern California with much-needed water, along with powerful winds and flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Serbia?
description: Can you find Serbia on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European nation with seven million people?
content: Can you find Serbia on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European nation with seven million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
title: Yes, There Has Been Progress on Climate. No, It’s Not Nearly Enough.
description: Nations have started making progress on climate change. But we’re still on track for dangerous warming unless those efforts accelerate drastically.
content: Nations have started making progress on climate change. But we’re still on track for dangerous warming unless those efforts accelerate drastically.
source.name: The New York Times

title: October Subscriber Digest
description: Stories popular with subscribers, curated by Times editors. Subscriber-exclusive features.
content: Stories popular with subscribers, curated by Times editors. Subscriber-exclusive features.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: David Sedaris Knows What You’ll Laugh at When No One Is Judging
description: “I love an old-fashioned vulgar joke.”
content: “I love an old-fashioned vulgar joke.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1 Million in California
description: A Queen Anne house in San Diego, a two-bedroom, split-level condominium in Berkeley and a midcentury-modern home in Altadena.
content: A Queen Anne house in San Diego, a two-bedroom, split-level condominium in Berkeley and a midcentury-modern home in Altadena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Protesters Defy Military Coup in Sudan
description: Pro-democracy protesters filled the streets of the capital, Khartoum, after the military detained the prime minister, suspended the government and declared a state of emergency in an apparent coup. At least three protesters were killed.
content: Pro-democracy protesters filled the streets of the capital, Khartoum, after the military detained the prime minister, suspended the government and declared a state of emergency in an apparent coup. At least three protesters were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Thanksgiving, Already?
description: With just a month to go, we’re getting prepped.
content: Good morning. We’re just a month out from Thanksgiving, 30 days from a holiday that last year was deeply strange for a lot of us and that this year promises — what, a return to everything as it was in 2019? Probably not. We’re excited about what’s coming, but nervous, too. We’re managing as best we can.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alec Baldwin and the Gun Tragedy
description: Readers discuss the fatal shooting on a movie set. Also: How disabled people should be treated; exhaustion after Trump.
content: To the Editor:
